Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I got a great survey of what is happening in China right now with some more contextualizing historical information.
Developed a better understanding of where China is now in the global stage and how it compares to where China was in the past.
Learned a lot of new things about the Chinese language and Chinese computing as well as some interesting history. We also covered a lot of current events in China.
Hard power soft power and BRI
I learned about a broad overview of Chinese history and culture.
Learned about issues in present day china
I learned about Chinas place in the modern world.

china in the world 
future china
past china
present china
Insight into six different hot topics relating to China

This class was pretty cool in that it taught lots of modern concepts pertaining to relations between the US and China. I felt like we covered a lot of really important topics. If you want baseline understanding about china in the modern world take this course.
how different china actually is from what we know here
Learned a lot about China, specifically its BRI initiative
A survey course regarding the most prominent topics regarding China today.
Great survey China course
We learned another different topics in relation to china, such as AI and the arctic.
Good intro course to all that is China and understanding their culture and how that has influenced their path on the global stage. Could be organized and developed better, however.
Developed my knowledge of chinas Role in the modern world and the tools and motivations for their spreading influence.

This course provided students with a broad overview of many of the most important topics in China today. Some of those topics included the Belt and Road Initiative, the Arctic, space travel, Chinese calligraphy, etc.
I learnt nothing, this was an awful class.
China current affairs
Not much really, the class wasn't well-structured for learning.
Interesting survey of a broad spectrum of Chinese current events and political affairs.

I learned a lot about various aspects about modern China - from the Belt and Road Initiative to expand in the world to its relationships with other nations, the importance of the Chinese language to innovations in technology - and how Chinese history has influenced China's position in the world and its approaches to dealing with different issues. This course was helpful for me to see what a powerful nation like China has done and is doing to further itself in the world.
History of china and its worldly affairs and language history

I learned about different aspects of China that I had not been aware of before and they were definitely aspects that I found to be useful knowledge, like the BRI and China's space program. A lot of the time, people don't research China on their own and even if they do, they may come across inaccurate information, but this class helped to clarify a lot of that.
Think critically about global issues, learn about Chinese philosophy and history.
I learn a lot about China in the US's perspective.
Nothing
a little discombobulated

I learned about the historical and cultural forces that have helped to create the China we know today -- we attacked these issues from many angles and ended up with a well-rounded understanding of the country's place in the modern world.
I didn't learn much. The lectures were really boring and not engaging at all.
I gained deeper insights about specific topics relating to modern China, including China's polar ambitions, the Belt and Road Initiative, and the origins of the Chinese typographical system.
Learned about China in its current position in the world today, ranging from BRI to AI to Space Exploration
Analyzing Economics/Politics of China
BRI

- Learned to view China more holistically
- Realized how many similarities (and how many striking differences) there are between Chinese history and Korean history (I am of Korean heritage)
How China interacts with the world
Not many. Very bad course.
We learnt about various issues in present day China.
You get a fascinating understanding behind some of the most important Chinese headlines.
I developed a more holistic view of China's current place in the world, how China operates, and how its history ties into its future ambitions.
I think I developed a more nuanced view of China and its interactions with the international community.
I learned about the historical context for the behavior and perspectives of modern China.
Got a general overview of Chinas place in international politics and the mindset of the Chinese government going into the future.

A lot of relevant material on the past, present, and future of China from a philosophical, economic, political, and societal context. Be able to have a knowledgeable conversation with anyone on China's state of affairs.

knowledge about China that I would not have known about had I not taken this class. it goes over more than what the average student in America reads about in the news so I thought it was a good insight into Chinese history, culture, and overall topics.
knowledge of China's history, modern movements
Its a good course for an introduction about China's domestic and foreign ambitions. good discussion

I learned about a lot of very interesting developments in China and China's growing presence in the world, as well as important historical background that informs the way we view China today and the way China views itself. Topics included the Belt Road Initiative, Chinese interactions with the West, Chinese science fiction, and even ancient Chinese geopolitical philosophy for context.
I developed a good understanding of how China is going to develop in the future, and how the rest of the world is going to react.
The class taught me more about the modern Chinese state and society, information well worth knowing on our world today.

The class has very interesting material that I found engaging and worthwhile. As a student interested in how Asian nations grapple with futurism and modernism, I found that this class was worthwhile. However, if you are not interested in China, East Asia, or maybe China's global influence, this class isn't for you. Also, I found the lecture size to be too big. There were over a hundred students enrolled in the class but it felt like less than half of them showed up. With the class relying heavily on discussions and class participation, I think that it should be capped in the future to ensure that engagement is there.

This class seems like it is tried to be taught like a seminar, but it is really a lecture. Forcing students to participate in class discussions (by passing the microphone around and telling a random person to answer a question) is very inappropriate, in my opinion, and participation should be totally optional.
It was a very big lecture that was taught like a seminar. Either the course needs to be restructured a bit or the size should get reduced.
This class needs to be taught as a small seminar...
It was a lecture of 190 people and the professor made every thursday a "discussion" day which obviously did not go well
The course could be improved by adding discussion sections or changing its seminar-lecture hybrid structure.

This course was very poorly organized. We touched on a lot of relevant topics and had a lot of interesting readings, but unfortunately the poor logistical planning of the course on behalf of the teaching staff really detracted from the quality of the course. Our readings oftentimes were not posted until a day or two before they were due, and there was also a general lack of communication and intimacy between the students and the TAs. Most notably, the professor would oftentimes come to class unprepared, with no slides and just a vague sense of direction, hoping that asking broad open-ended questions would amount to an hour's worth of class. That being said, Jing Tsu is a captivating and charismatic speaker and an engaging professor. I think teaching this course in such a big lecture isn't optimal for learning, and is a waste of a great professor.
Very informative, does not need to be improved the assignments were interesting and manageable
The course was interesting but I thought the professor was unclear with how she was going to grade her students.

Strength: Jin 
Weakness: lack of feedback, a little unstructured, too large of a class, sometimes irrelevant readings, topics jumped around a little too much, could use a little more focus

We learned about six disparate topics and didn't put them together in any way. It felt disjointed. As a weakness, we received absolutely no guidelines for the film project, but it's clear (from what I was later emailed by a TA) that there were definitely guidelines by which the TAs and professor graded.
poor attempt at trying to force a large lecture to interact like a seminar
They stopped taking attendance halfway through so I dont know how they will grade participation

Touches as many aspects of China as possible, many of the course readings were not academic but elements of popular culture. 

It felt scattered at times, and the final project was forced in trying to apply pigeonholed class concepts to a topic that did not necessitate them.
Unorganized content and grading system

Strength: Professor Tsu was really knowledgable
Weakness: The class structure was not engaging. Leccure would be on Tuesday and a discussion would be on Thursday. I did not learn much on Thursday. I think we could have covered a wider range of topics. We seemed to spend a long amount of time on some topics, such as AI and technology, which meant we couldn't cover other topic such as Chinese military.
It's amazing material... just needs more development. Some days are amazing and so interesting and others are not as much.
The biweekly assignments were often very abstract, it made it easier to wonder off track and not submit what the graders were hoping for. More TF involvement would be an improvement.

I thought Professor Tsu was a strength in terms of her passion and knowledge on the subjects. Also, I thought it did a good job of covering many key topics in just a semester. However, the other side of that is that at times the course felt disconnected from some of the other things that we had covered; we were bouncing around from one topic to the next, so a more clear direction for the course might help students take-away a couple of key points from the semester.
It would have been a good class in a seminar setting. However, as a lecture (with in-lecture discussion?), it was awful.
Great lectures and thought-provoking writing assignments

The instructor failed to structure the in-class debate in a meaningful and effective way, leaving broad questions to the class that no-one had answers to. The lectures also wasn't planned out well, and it is clear that the effort put into preparing this class frankly wasn't adequate - she would drag on an discussion/monologue without any substance, and still end up letting us leave early. Since the assignments are so easy, it is almost impossible to discern good students from bad ones in terms of grading. I am overall really disappointed in how the prof taught this class, not only failing to teach in an effective way, but also letting discussions go way out of hand, where some fairly offensive comments are blatantly made.

Interesting material that is extremely important, but the course sometimes felt flowery and the readings were overly onerous, which discouraged anyone from doing them. The film final project format I felt did not help encourage my learning or processing of the material.

This course does a great job in providing information and perspective about many different aspects of modern China, how it came to be, and what exactly they are doing in order to develop their society and global status. All of the readings were very interesting, and I enjoyed doing them. Being able to engage with different forms of material - news articles, historical reports, UN and other global organization reports, a movie, and science fiction writing - was really great because it allowed me to really analyze the issues at hand through a variety of media, and I learned more because of that.

For me, one of the main weaknesses of the course was the size. I feel like this course would have been much more meaningful and beneficial if it were taught as a seminar rather than a lecture, because it would give students the opportunity to really reflect on the material and share their opinions. Professor Tsu tried to facilitate class discussions, but it was never very effective because not many people want to participate in a lecture-wide discussion in Davies Auditorium. I felt like the discussions, then, were very detached because it's very difficult to have a meaningful discussion with your peers when you cannot really see or acknowledge the other people. I also would've liked more feedback on the assignments, since I never received comments once I got the grades back and I would've liked comments on what I could improve if I got points taken off for some reason. There also were no criteria for what the TAs were looking for in terms of grading our assignments, and that would have been helpful to know what they were looking for so that we could have given the proper details or level of analysis in our assignments. Instead, it kind of felt like shooting an arrow in the dark and hoping that it turned out okay.

strengths:
interesting, pretty low workload

weaknesses;
would be much better as a seminar, not very engaging

Strengths: Interesting topics, interesting reading assignments

Weaknesses: The "discussions" each week were hard to engage in. There were way too many people in that class to be able to effectively have deep discussions. This class needs discussion sections each week. The TAs seem interested enough to do it and it would be so useful for students.
I think it was taught as a seminar, but was a lecture, which made it hard to engage in fully.

The class size is too big, making it hard to conduct deeper intellectual discussion in the class. Even though there is weekly reading responses, the level of engagement and discussion is not as satisfying as an in-class discussion.

A lot of interesting topics have been covered, but the readings are quite heavy.

Strengths: very cool material.

Weaknesses: the grading structure made no sense AT ALL. How can participation count for 30% of my grade when there are 500 people in lecture and there is no section? What? I also had very little communication with my TA. Major assignments were not explained well.
Better professor.
i think it would be more interesting to talk about current events, like relations with the US and russia

This course is designed badly -- it is a low-engagement 150-person lecture that the professor attempts to run as a discussion-based seminar, so many of the students that actually continue to show up week after week (much fewer than 150) end up repeatedly projecting their opinions to the room with little opportunity for critical discussion. The class as currently designed would work well if it were very small, and Jing Tsu is a great professor despite her strange choices about the course format. I have one main recommendation: this class MUST have mandatory sit-down discussion sections for it to play the role it should on campus, since the content is so important. 

Also I'm not sure why we focused so many of the final weeks of the semester on Chinese science fiction -- I realize that it involves imagining a future and that there are interesting cultural threads to follow there, but it did not feel important enough for the amount of time we spent on it.

The class could've been more interactive. They were assigning a lot of pages of reading for every lecture, and because of the heavy workload people didn't actually do the work and therefore couldn't participate. I would reduce the amount of reading by a lot.

The lectures started out very interesting and thought-provoking, but over time they devolved in very general discussions about technology and media that were not China specific. The aspect of lecture participation was also not conducive to learning.

Strength: Fairly interesting, not too much work 
Weakness: Kind of all over the place at times

Weakness: It's a lecture but designed like a seminar. Makes it difficult for students to participate also confuses the grading process. The assignments are also posted two days before, which gives us less time to offer more thoughtful responses. No grading rubric, so your grade is largely dependent on your TA.
Dont treat it like a seminar
It was very unorganized and took months to get a 500 word paper corrected.
Needs a discussion section. The lecture discussions were not engaging and boxed out kids who might not want to speak in a big lecture

- Jing Tsu is an extremely eloquent and charming professor (was unafraid to discuss a wide variety of topics, all of which related to China in one way or another)
- One weakness/aspect I would change: more conversation on controversial topics (such as the current Muslim genocide in China, or the negative implications the one child policy had in China)
Good introduction to various topics
It tried to make a lecture a seminar and discussion-based. Didnt work.

Strengths: very interesting readings and Professor Tsu is a great lecturer. 
Weaknesses: the course was supposed to have a much lower workload than it ended up having.
I think perhaps the course would benefit from a separate discussion section.
The course material is interesting, but when presented in a lecture format it feels unorganized and messy at times.

I didn't feel the course did anything particularly well. The material jumped all over there place and didn't seem to have a cohesive message, class discussions weren't engaging for most, and the assessments left a lot to be desired.

Strengths: up-to-date on current issues, assignments encouraged critical analysis of the primary material
Weaknesses: in-class discussions were sometimes a bit scattered and not very useful, and the attendance policy was cumbersome and inefficient early on for such a large class
This course was fine, but honestly should have been a seminar. Our prof tried to keep us all engaged by having us answer questions out loud, but in a class of 200 it just wasnt feasible.

Content covered was very relevant. The weekly reading responses and biweekly essays were a lot of work, and much of it felt forced and rather than organic. The discussion lectures were a highlight of the class, but due to the large class size, it ended up being the same couple of students speaking every time. If this class had a discussion section, it might have been a better way for students to express their opinions and present arguments synthesized from the readings.
it was a good course could have been improved by having more engaging TAs, i didn't know who mine was until the very last assignment because we had little conversation with our TAs.
shorter readings so that people will actually read them and engage more in lecture
its highly discussion based, and I enjoy the diverse take on the same issue

Strengths: fascinating topics, great lecturer (Jing Tsu), some really interesting guest speakers, very relevant material
Weaknesses: almost no participation because the discussion setting is a bit awkward, reading responses were often bland since they were often due before we discussed the material in lecture. I also felt like the class petered off towards the end of the semester, it felt like the lectures were less organized and the content was less interesting
I think that there should be more frequent meetings with the TF's in an attempt to make the understandings in class more solidified.

The course had a very manageable workload and some interesting lectures.

I think the part of the curriculum dedicated to art and culture needs to be omitted. I and everyone I know found it terribly boring and useless. I wish we spend substantially more time on China's economy (e.g., recent expansion of Arctic shipping lanes, Chinese SOEs in Africa and in the Belt and Road Initiative). That would be far more interesting and relevant. I found myself glued to the lectures on that content but not so much on Chinese calligraphy.

I would say this class is a fairly easy Humanities credit, if you are needing it or are interested in the subject. However, the professor has unrealistic expectations for a lecture of this size, and should make the readings more manageable. I got away this semester with doing essentially none of the readings, but at times it was difficult as many of our writing assignments were based on the readings. However, the amount of readings assigned for this are excessive and quite frankly, annoying. (for example, 800 pages were assigned over spring break). Additionally, if things go quiet during discussions, the prof. will pass around the microphone throughout the audience (particularly those in the back of the auditorium) and then randomly choose a person to talk when he/she receives the microphone. Overall, the class is a good way to knock out a humanities credit and do fairly well, but the class itself could be quite annoying and frustrating at times.
Not a bad 6th credit for a STEM major. Definitely not a gut, but the workload was manageable and pretty easy. Lots of reading that wasn't always discussed and several short essays.

No. This class was not some thing I would take again. There was very little work, but I feel like I got very little out of the class and came away know nothing more than I would have scanning the New York Times.
It is definitely an easy workload but you get what you want to get out of it.
I would recommend this course as an easy fifth class with relevant content, since will teach you about a rising global power.
Yes I would, great way to get exposure to modern issues in China
Yes because the material was very interesting.

If you've found this course, you've likely filtered by workload. We both know why you're considering taking it. And yeah, it's a pretty good course in that regard. Not very challenging, so a good fifth credit if you need one.

Yes and no, if this class goes back to the leminar version then maybe; i think a lot of students take it just because it "sounds" easy; but i think the class would be much better if it was more engaging if there were people in it that actually cared (there were definitely some, but not the vast majority)

Otherwise, it IS really interesting to learn about China in the world, good introduction to China as well
Good readings sometimes, sometimes bad reading; hit or miss
Solid gut.
If you're interested in contemporary China, yes.

If you want a basic understanding of China in the modern world, take this course. The final project was also really fun. I felt like the professor was really engaged with our learning experience the whole time. It was just hard because the class size was so big that the TF's would grade most of our stuff, and they provided a lot less feedback than we should have gotten.
It was easy but not organized
Yes, its an interesting class and not hard

For China experts to novices, there is something for everyone. Even those who had a lot of prior knowledge could learn a lot from interacting with other students and seeing how they viewed certain events. 

Workload was not heavy, but there is little feedback received throughout the course and grading is not very clear. Even when attendance was taken, many people did not show up and half the class was not very engaged. Difficult to interact with required class discussion posts when many responders were clearly unknowledgeable about the topics.
Yes
If you want an easy class, yes. If not - no. It isn't engaging and I did not learn much.
I would.
It's a good class if you don't know anything about China or current east asian affairs, but since I already knew most of it, I didn't learn as much as I expect/as I could.

Yes! I think China is a rapidly growing country that will affect many of our futures, no matter the careers we choose. Understanding a little more about all of the topics we covered in class will only help.
Yes, especially if you have little knowledge of Chinese affairs.

No. The instructor failed to structure the in-class debate in a meaningful and effective way, leaving broad questions to the class that no-one had answers to. The lectures also wasn't planned out well, and it is clear that the effort put into preparing this class frankly wasn't adequate - she would drag on an discussion/monologue without any substance, and still end up letting us leave early. Since the assignments are so easy, it is almost impossible to discern good students from bad ones in terms of grading. I am overall really disappointed in how the prof taught this class, not only failing to teach in an effective way, but also letting discussions go way out of hand, where some fairly offensive comments are blatantly made.

I would recommend this course to another student. While the grading policies and the set-up of the class (in terms of class discussions in Davies) were kind of strange, I did learn a ton in this class and I've been able to talk with people, including the Chinese members of my family, about issues involving modern China to a much greater extent than I could have before taking this class. It really gave me a lot of perspective on another country, which is important to me because I want to be able to learn about other nations and what they are doing in the world, not just focusing on the United States. Also, there wasn't too much work in this class and it served as a nice break from the heavier classes in my schedule while still teaching a lot of very interesting and cool material.
Not sure

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, because it was so interesting and Professor Tsu's guest speakers were so useful. The topics, from China's space program, to the Belt Road Initiative, to Chinese science fiction were extremely engaging topics that I will think about for years to come. This course brought my attention to so many topics that I had not thought of before and I am so glad that I took this course.
No, because it is difficult to fully engage with the material
The readings are quite heavy although some of them are really interesting.
Dont take this class unless you need to.
it was fine, but i think a little disorganized
Yes, since the content is incredibly interesting and useful, but it needs to be redesigned to engage people who take it as a gut.
No. I didn't enjoy it at all.

I was genuinely so excited to take this class, but after 6-7 weeks found myself completely disillusioned. Though the topics/syllabus were interesting, the execution was terrible. We spent tons of time discussing Chinese language and writing, which made it very exclusionary for people who cannot speak Chinese in any capacity. I took this class precisely because I know nothing about China/wanted an overview, and found myself being told to "stay away from stereotypes" that I did not even understand in their entirety before taking the course. Watching movies like Wolf Warrior 2, in all honesty, only reinforced some of these stereotypes for me. 

Cold-calling in lecture was the absolute worst. I understand that it is to no one's benefit to not do class readings, but it made me dread going to lecture because I would feel that if I could not provide a substantive enough answer (as someone who is not Chinese and knows very little about China), I could be told in front of the entire class that my answer was a "nice, easy, off-the-cuff response that next time should be better", as was told to other students in a full lecture hall. Especially when long readings are assigned over school breaks, I always felt like I was doing tons of busy work for no reason, that in no way enhanced my understanding of what initially seemed like interesting topics. I also felt that the general environment was very hostile and competitive since in-class participation counted for so much of our gradepeople who have been able to travel/live in China would have many more confident points to make compared to others simply trying to understand ideas, and these points often had nothing to do with the readings (which is perfectly OK, but likely defeats the purpose of putting so much weight on a participation grade). 

Finally, the final project made little to no sense from my point of view. My team spent more time trying to figure out how to make a video on iMovie, and how to delegate responsibility amongst ourselves (i.e. it is cumbersome to try to have 4 people come to agreements on creative ideas for how a film script should work), than actually thinking about the topics we covered throughout the year in any way. Meeting with the TA when we were stuck brought us tons of confusion with ZERO clarity, since we were left to "think about everything a bit more and try to figure it out." There were no guidelines provided until after we submitted the assignment, so it was incredibly stressful for reasons entirely separate from the class material and trying to grapple with it. 

I would not recommend to take this classmy experience with it, regardless of a final grade, was not easy, pleasant, or academically enriching. This is a shame, since so many people discuss China in all of my other classes and I really wanted to walk away with some semblance of profound understanding.
I would recommend this course to another student. Class was graded relatively easy which took pressure away from technicalities and allowed for honest learning.
It's definitely an exciting course to learn more about the ins and outs of China's geopolitical rise, but it was not as intellectually rigorous as I had hoped.
It's a good fifth class and if you put the work in you'll learn a lot
Needs to be reorganized. Should either be offered as a seminar or a lecture with more standardization across TA's.
I absolutely would. I really appreciated the contemporary focus of the class in particular!
No

Yes, especially if you are interested in learning more about Chinese society, culture, and history. If you are not interested in China at all, it is still a nice lecture class that you will learn something from (Professor Tsu's passion makes it pretty impossible to ignore the course, even if you have zero interest in China)
Yes! Easy course, professor Tsu is nice and knows what she's talking about
No
Yes, its a good humanities credit and is great if you are interested in learning about China.
I would recommend this class to all majors. It is super interesting and you get out of the class as much as you put in.

If there are sections and it's not just one giant lecture, then I would definitely recommend this course. Otherwise, I would be hesitant, but you do get a decent amount out of this class even without it.
No, I think a student would be better served doing their own guided reading on China. Class discussions and assignments didn't add particularly much.

Yes, the professor is very knowledgeable about all the course material covered, and the topics are all pretty interesting for anyone wanting to learn more about China. However, the course can feel a bit unorganized at certain points.

If youre looking for a light workload class to add and are fine being one of hundreds of faces in a lecture, go for it. Otherwise, there might be other courses that offer more engagement while covering the same topic.

Yes. The content is this class naturally changes as China's position in the world changes, so the material covered never becomes out-of-date. If you want a good crash course in China, this is the class to take.
yes because China is an important actor in world politics and I think it is important to learn more about their history.
For sure! its a great class
Yes, I think it is a really interesting class and the material is extremely relevant.
Yes, it gives a nice insight into China and allows one to have a good understanding of how America and Chinese relations are going to develop in the future.

You can do well in this course without too much work. And some parts are interesting (Chinese economy, Arctic shipping lanes, state-owned enterprises in Africa, etc) while others are dreadful (Chinese calligraphy).
